awd_titl_txt: NeuroNex Theory Team: Inferring interactions between neurons, stimuli, and behavior
awd_abstract_narration:
Scientists have learned much about how the activity of individual neurons relates to sensations, thoughts, feelings, and behavior. However, all neurons live and function within the enormous web that is the brain. Scientists are still far from understanding how the complex, dynamic dance between the cells that form this web makes us who we are. While new technologies allow scientists to observe the activity of massive numbers of neurons in living brains, they still cannot make sense of such data. The goal of this NeuroNex Theory team is to develop a new lens - a set of mathematical and computational tools - for making sense of the dynamic brain activity data. These techniques will allow them to deduce when and how observed neurons interact, how these interactions are altered by stimuli, and how they may govern behavior. The resulting combination of revolutionary experimental and mathematical tools will provide neuroscientists with unprecedented insights into the brain's distributed neural computations.

This NeuroNex Theory team will develop statistical tools that will provide insights into the computations performed by neuronal ensembles, by relating what the animal observes to recorded neural activity as well as how the neural activity relates to behavior. They will validate the methods using simulated neuronal networks, and apply them to recordings from the mouse brain. The team will also develop and test their approach using modern deep neural networks (convolutional nets and recurrent architectures) that achieve or exceed human performance in many hard tasks. This will allow them to quantify how interactions in these artificial networks change with the stimulus, and compare and contrast the results with data from animals. This is a broad set of goals that requires a combination of approaches and diverse expertise. The team therefore consists of experimental and theoretical neuroscientists, mathematicians, and statisticians who will work together closely. The true test of this work will be the impact it will have on brain science in general. The team is therefore committed to sharing their techniques, code and data. They have also assembled a group of End Users to be early adopters and testers of these methods. This NeuroNex Theory Team award is funded as part of the BRAIN Initiative and NSF's Understanding the Brain activities.

por.por_cntn:
The Houston NeuroNex theory group has completed the major proposed goals developing computational and theoretical methods for the analysis and interpretation of large scale recordings of neural activity. We have helped develop infrastructure both locally in the Houston area and nationally to continue these efforts. Our work was conducted collaboratively between all six participating labs and shows how innovative methods and interdisciplinary approaches can uncover fundamental principles of neural connectivity and dynamics. Training a new generation of neuroscientists who can work at the interface of experimental neuroscience, statistics, and applied mathematics was an integral part of this effort: The grant supported over a dozen PhD students, and postdoctoral associates, and resulted in 69 published articles. These trainees have continued to careers in experimental neuroscience and data science in academia and industry.  

The project addressed overlapping themes, linking neural connectivity, function, and learning across biological and artificial systems. A central theme of our research was understanding the relationship between connectivity and computation in neural circuits. To achieve this, Dr. Pitkow's team developed advanced statistical models to capture higher-order interactions in probabilistic graphical models, enabling the study of neural circuit computations and their parallels in artificial neural networks like transformers. This work not only provided insights into how the brain processes information but also created a bridge between biological circuits and modern AI architectures, demonstrating shared computational motifs. Such insights were also provided by other supported projects.

Collaborations between the experimental team member, Dr. Tolias and theorists on the team further developed the relationship between connectivity and function. Drs. Pitkow and Tolias proposed a framework for how anatomical networks might implicitly implement computational algorithms, offering a new perspective on how neural circuits perform complex computations. Tolias’s lab, in collaboration with Pitkow, expanded this work by studying the mouse visual cortex, integrating cutting-edge imaging and machine learning to examine how connectivity shapes function. Their analysis revealed key principles, such as a "like-to-like" connectivity rule, where neurons with similar tuning properties preferentially form connections. Deep learning models developed by the lab demonstrated that nonlinear tuning to visual stimuli better predicts connectivity than traditional measures, reshaping our understanding of how sensory information is processed.  Drs. Rosenbaum and Josić helped explain these findings with a simple neural network model, and related them to classical attractor models in computational neuroscience. 

Another core aspect of our work was the development of tools to analyze large-scale neural data, exemplified by the Allen lab’s contributions. The graph-learning methods developed by Dr. Allen and her team, designed to infer connectivity from massive calcium imaging datasets, addressed challenges such as handling non-Gaussian data and dealing with unobserved variables. These tools are transformative for computational neuroscience, enabling more accurate and comprehensive studies of large neural populations. The methodologies complement the broader theme of understanding neural connectivity across scales, as seen in the analysis of the Drosophila connectome using network science approaches conducted by Drs. Pitkow and Josić, along with collaborators and trainees. This work showed that brain of the fly has anatomical structures that can be detected as interconnected modules, providing insights into how connectivity principles can drive neural computations.

In addition to analyzing neural connectivity, the team explored neural dynamics and plasticity. Dr. Pitkow, in collaboration with neurosurgeon Dr. Tandon, applied hierarchical models to human brain recordings during language tasks, uncovering a regular sequence of network states. This work linked dynamic changes in brain networks to functional outcomes, providing a framework for understanding how neural circuits adapt to cognitive demands. Drs. Josić, Rosenbaum, and trainees, in collaboration with experimental neuroscientists, studied rapid plasticity in monkey visual cortex (V1) under optogenetic stimulation. Their computational model offered experimental and theoretical evidence for homeostatic plasticity, emphasizing its role in maintaining the stability of neural activity.

Theoretical advancements in artificial neural networks and their relation to neural computations were another focus of this effort. Dr. Patel’s group investigated the inductive biases that enable neural networks to learn and generalize effectively. These findings have profound potential implications for understanding both artificial and biological learning systems. Dr. Patel’s team also extended this work to the Neural Tangent Kernel (NTK), collaborating with Dr. Cohen at Princeton to explore how attention and multitasking trade-offs in neural networks align with psychological theories.

Training and career development were integral to this project. Our trainees continued to postdoctoral and faculty positions in prestigious labs, as well as a variety of positions in industry. These successes underscore the collaborative and interdisciplinary nature of the research, which provided trainees with diverse opportunities to contribute to cutting-edge neuroscience.

In summary, this project advanced our understanding of neural connectivity, dynamics, and computation, linking biological and artificial systems through shared computational principles. Our collaborative efforts lead to methodological and theoretical innovations, providing a foundation for future studies of the principles that govern neural systems across scales and species.
